comments.commentBody: Then you would not mind it if the US declared itself a "Christian" state?

Not to blow your bubble, TBS, but things ARE bad. We live in a time when separation based on silly, external things like religion, race, income, political party, and even gender threatens all of  humanity.  We have shared interests and it is long past time to begin exploring these shared interests rather than what seemingly separates us.  For you to say "I do not concern myself with Arabs..."  is a mistake.  You cannot ask from another what you yourself will not give.

You know what, TBS?  Any defense of Israel and its right-wing lunatic leader just rings untrue and frankly ignorant.  Israel is wrong.  Israel is behaving in an evil way and using our money and military aid to persecute and kill innocent people.  How can anyone defend that?  Israel is a rogue, apartheid state with virtually no friends left in the world.  If the few friends it has left would just refuse to send them money, their behavior would change.

No one cares what religion you are or aren`t. Zionism is the problem. It has evolved to believe that the "END" a Jewish homeland justifies the "MEANS" , the ethnic cleansing of the indigenous people of Palestine by Europeans who as even historians know & now genetic studies show are the descendants of European converts to Judaism from the Roman Empire ers + the Khazars who converted c750 CE. Ie. The Ashkenazi are not a Semitic people (no Near East DNA). eg. In 1918 , Ben Gurion & Y. Ben Zvi (PM for 2 decades & 2nd pres of Israel respectively) coauthored a history of Israel in which they agreed with professional historians that there was no exile of Jews from Roman Palestine in the 1st or 2nd century AD. They agreed that most of the populace (90%+) stayed in place and that a majority of them converted to Islam in the 7th century.
A 2013 genetic study found: "Ashkenazi Jews do not stem from Hebrews" http://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1208/1208.1092.pdf. ie They are not from the Near East while of course the Sephardic Jews & Palestinians are both Semitic peoples.

I am not religious, but I am Jewish.

There should be one Jewish state: Israel. Without it, Jews would have no where to run if things got bad. The fact is that around the world countries know that if they persecute their Jewish minorities (or permit rogue persecution by Muslims or anyone else) Israel takes an interest and would not countenance it. Israel would (and does) offer safe haven for Jews around the world.

There are (I think) twenty two Arab Muslim nations. There are more than a dozen Christian nations. There are more than thirty (I believe) Muslim nations all told.

There is one Jewish nation.

It happens to be on soil that is holy to those among them who are religious. The most holy land for them – this is a bonus.

There were 100 million refugees after WWII who were not returned to their land.

I do not concern myself with Arabs in Israel – be they Palestinian or Arab citizens.

There are 350 million Arabs living in hostile countries around Israel – these Arabs in Israel could be sent there in a worst case scenario.

My concern: one Jewish state.

Many Arabs came to Israel to work when the yishuv was being formed. That’s where the jobs were.

Why do Mexicans and Central Americans come to the US in droves? Same reason: jobs.

Let’s keep Israel a Jewish refuge for now and ever more. One state. Just one. Stop the baloney that it’s unfair: tell it to the Muslim and Christian states – count them first: you will be lecturing half the world.

There's a high chance the nationality law will pass in the coming year, and everything will be ok, because this law is not ultra-nationalistic and won't change the individual rights of any citizen in Israel.
The day these ultra-nationalistic bills pass should be the day the US withdraws any and all foreign aid to Israel.
Jews were there thousands of years before the Palestinians and had always lived in Judea and Samaria.   Jews were there when other Jews arrived in 1948.

Unfortunately, Israeli democracy is not like US  democracy. When you have block voting according to a Rabbi's instructions, the idea of an independent polity is abrogated. Note that Israelis do not vote for persons, they vote for a party, which then selects.
I guess David Ben-Gurion, who offered Einstein the presidency of Israel in 1952, did not share your perspective on the criterion for being Israel's president. How times have changed.

These 2 comments are good examples of the judgemental attitudes mentioned in the article

We are lucky to have the means and time to cook healthy meals most nights. Yet, despite of our somewhat flexible schedules, sometimes we end up ordering take out. Fortunately for us, we can afford better quality take out than fast food, but that is because of our privilege.

I can see how some with lesser means, less flexible schedules, a long commute, who are trying to run a household on their own, or any combination of the above, may struggle putting healthy food on the table every night. That's not even accounting for how cheaply places like McDonald's allow people to fill their bellies.

Criticism of those who eat fast food on a frequent basis because it's cheap usually includes comments about how much cheaper and healthier are beans and rice. True, but what if you are just a bad cook and/or your kids are sick of eating that?

I'm not arguing that choosing fast or otherwise unhealthy food over other options is good. We all know it negatively affects the individual and society.

Still, we should consider the systemic causes to this issue before we judge others from our privileged positions. Let's not forget that some don't have the means, live in food deserts, don't know how to cook, were raised on fast or otherwise unhealthy food, etc.

I can't agree with this.  I fail to see, for instance, how wearing a necklace with a cross on it, as many I know do, is "in your face" any more than I understand a head scarf that way.  And I know many folks who wear "hoodies," including myself, but none that obscure their faces with them.

tell me, why should he get credit for gas prices being low? It's the market over supply that is responsible for that, via fracking  oil and nat gas which was planned out and executed by Bush Jr. back in 2001/2 with Congress passing laws to make development of fracking oil/gas easier.. Obama had nothing to do with it.. he can claim the fame along with Bush for our deficit, along with many poor /middle class lives ruined.

Jack, your reply is incoherent to start with (where do you get "insulating YOURSELF"), ignorant ("life-or-death wartime" -- you swallowed the right-wing, militarist KoolAid), incoherent and offensive ("a fool ... extremely selfish" -- where did you dream that up from? not anything I said) and simultaneously incoherent, ignorant, and offensive ("your own self esteem and your lofty utopian ideals").  You know nothing of me.  Let's be equally forthright: You write like you've been swallowed by the armchair warriors who want other people to pay and to die for their fantasies of world control.

and sorry again about my silly comments - as we have the word of Pres. Putin that the whole deal (again) is a conspiracy of Anglo-America Money Men - and as I always make abundantly clear that I also believe in such a conspiracy -(to a certain extent) - Especially after a lot of the Russian money is now in London - and I have witnessed how our 'Degenerated American Lifestyle 'poisened' Russian Souls to the utmost degree and now the need - absolutely NEED a 'Flat' in London or at least a Penthouse in Manhattan - and so we actually don#t have to worry too much - after nearly every Rich Russian will have left his homeland -(and settles in London or on Park Avenue) we could do 'the coup' there to 'overthrow' them?
Larry--Please explain to me how a "hoodie" is ethnic.  Thanks!

The greatest worry of Cheney and Rogers is not Pakistanis and Yemenis learning about the disgusting crimes committed by the CIA in their countries. It is the possibility of an informed American citizenry that makes them wake up at night, drenched in sweat.

Until we know exactly what was done in our names, it will be too easy for some to look the other way, shrug, say, "they must have done something to deserve it/they don't matter/they're our enemies".  I think the descriptions of what happened to individuals will make a real difference. I recall reading about a man who was kidnapped by the U.S. because someone thought he knew something.  He was slowly beaten to death.  Had he lived, his legs would have been amputated because they were so badly damaged.  What kind of human does this, for any reason?  We have to face the reality in order to prevent it.  Maybe some won't be so bloodthirsty for the next war when they know what horrors our representatives are capable of.

Is President Obama and his staff along with Diane Feinstein so out of touch that what they say today contradicts such events such as the Seal Team 6's attempt to rescue Luke Somers.

Don't they realize this report will possibly ignite more hostage taking and probably speed up the deaths of any US and western citizens already being held hostage by terrorists?

But then again it is their politics that take precedent .....

The U.S. should not have used torture, but it did, and there's nothing that can change that. We can't run the clock back and undo the damage caused by it. However, what makes the U.S. different from other countries is its ability to publicly acknowledge mistakes.

The Republican lawmakers shouldn't be scared of releasing the report. Instead, they should encourage other countries to do the same. And how hypocrite can Dick Cheney be? As the Vice President, he should have been well aware of the consequences of torture, not have ordered it, and know that his day of reckoning would eventually come when the report is released. By suggesting that the report should not be released, he merely shows he is a coward hiding in secrecy.
The truth makes us free.

Obama and company must remember these words should 1 American or western citizen die due to this release:

"While the United States has put diplomatic facilities and military bases on alert for heightened security risks, administration officials said they do not expect the report -- or rather the declassified executive summary of it that will be released Tuesday -- to ignite the kind of violence that killed four Americans at a diplomatic outpost in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012. Such violent reprisals, they said, tend to be fueled more by perceived attacks against Islam as a religion than by violence against individual Muslims."

Christopher--Never mind religion, my kids have been Democrats since birth, and remain so in their 20's.

Although what you say may well be true, I suspect you know exactly what the author means when she says her daughter is Muslim.

So, the executive branch approved torture by the executive branch saying it was "Legal".

C'mon!, it's a no brainer!........that means it was illegal.
The US refuses to acknowledge the jurisdiction of the ICC, and has never approved the treaty that created it. That's one reason Dick Cheney et al are not in front of the Hague right now.

The reason that the International Criminal Court hasn't issued arrest warrants for Bush, Cheney, et al. is that the United States is one of the very few countries in the world that refuses to subject itself to the jurisdiction of the ICC.  And today, we can once again see why.

The US never joined the ICC, therefor the US is not obligated to turn over anyone to the court. The rational was that the US was afraid that combat troops would be prosecuted for crimes committed during our various wars. Of course the other rational was that the US is capable of punishing our own war criminals. Obviously this turned out to be untrue.

'The International Criminal Court (ICC) is the first ever permanent, treaty-based, international criminal court. It was established to promote the rule of law and to ensure that the gravest international crimes do not go unpunished. The Court tries persons accused of the most serious crimes of international concern, namely genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes.'

So where are the arrest warrants?

U. S. Law, International Law, The U. S. Code of Military Justice, The Geneva Conventions were all flouted and ignored by the Bush administration in violation of basic rules of war and humane behavior, which we were legally required to follow. They controlled the Presidency, the Senate, the House of Representatives and the Supreme Court at that time and were able to override any resistance. The "legal" gymnastics required for their distortions of the law were mindless.

It was a far cry from the latter stages and aftermath of World War II , when German mothers were telling their sons to surrender to the Americans
"because they don't torture" and the military and civilian interrogators at the Nuremberg Trials publicly stated that they "kept their humanity", did not permit torture and got much more info from the Nazi leaders than if they had. We had suffered such enormous casualties and trauma and yet we kept the moral high ground; a lesson, among many, ignored by the Bush administration. The predicament here is whether or not we have really learned a lesson and can again become a positive moral force in the world.

Someone wise once said "The Truth Shall Set You Free. Maybe we should try it.

You raise an interesting question that begs an answer. Neocon roots go back to Barry Goldwater who proposed considering nuking Vietnam because "extremism  in defense of your country is no vice". It's the same creed as Al Qaeda, Taliban, and ISIS, believers in waging war of total annihilation.

This sounds like an implicit admission by the GOP that the US is attacked, not because people around the world hate our freedoms, but because of the violence and oppression we have imposed on them. I have no idea whether the release of this report will result in increased violence against diplomatic facilities and military bases. I'd like to think that full disclosure and a promise to completely remediate the problem--carried out publicly--as well as punishment for those approved and engaged in torture would impress upon the world that we are in reality who we alone have deluded ourselves into believing we are. There just isn't much chance of us taking full responsibility here; the world will see our hypocrisy.
God should have helped Bush & the R party when they were making these awful decisions.
